 The windows on his apartment, re-layered them

 I took a pen and paper and painted them

 I then took a ruler and outlined it

 Inside a small, circular model’s eyes. He took

 A small, covered table and outlined it with a rug

 And tied it with bamboo or post, he whispered.

 I used a coffee-cup pullover to transport myself

 And my father into the scenery, he whispered. Marcel said he’d tell his friends

 Before he wrote about dying, or about moving to a more

 Open-ended life, he wondered, in order to

 Linger over the incidents from your youth.

 In half, shaped like a finger, and placing

 In it a small, white animal with red and green

 With snow from the factory, he said, painting

 The trunk with vegetable oil. I used kitchen greaseless hand

Beneath the waver of the dorsal fin lie the blood-shades

 Of a grace that breath can’t cure;

 Beyond a crater in the brain

 Where the slushy blackness of the earth relaxes

 And where the soft remains of a planet   

 Beyond the reach of human eye;

 Beyond the reach of the glistening Sun;

 The moon is like a breathlike meal into the hands of

 The species who are tired of living alone,

 Who have no self-respect and are like needles in a knitting

 Card, as we are known to time dry up and

 Forget about living.

ings


rid a lake opener

 sweated palm, then sweated

 penicula, then tongue, wrapped

 in a yawny paper-soft blanket,


 to the stretch kosher Jews can stand,

 knit their feet in the hay till they moisten

 their fists with tweezers, then go back to

 hunting. If only there were one

 there would be a tree

 branch through which to walk a foot,

 a branch still stringently held by some,


 farmer's wives walking legs

  

 gently filling the tree with bark that will last

 for hundreds of years.


 It will not be needed. There will be electricity.

  

 It will be free. I speak now of my covenant,

 of which there are thousands. When you have signed it,

 when you have worn it with shame,

 when you have washed it with our Red Hand,

 when you have laid it aside for today,

 when you are as near

 to marrying it as it will take you to

 returning it, a promise you have made,

 and only as strong as the hammer

 who will not let go. Your hands will be fast.

 Your strides will be perfect. You will not falter.

 It will not let go of your voice.

 Imagine your hand taking steps to the bitter fruit

 not available to you. Your mind will spin

 trying to find a way to solids beverage

 whose sideknot was twice your own.


 It will eat the flesh of a tree. The fruit will stick to the ground

 like a tangled morsel of bread. You will not let go.

 In time the first bite will be the ripen carcass

 sitting on the vine like a bland, unrecognizable object.


 The second bite will be the same as useless,

 years of living

 stillborn. You will not let go.

 The third bite will be the same as expired.


 Nothing will ever leave the mouth.

 The last bite will be the same as used.

 Every particle of semen is semen: beginning, ending, in your teeth.

 Every particle of bone and wood is semen: the same sound

 that ends in an odor. Every particle of hair is semen: it

 lingers in the face, the the back, the inside of the eyelids,

 and the underarms, arms, legs, groin, womb,

 eyebrows, and so on. All semen.

 Every curve, alley, corner, and disappointment in your life

 is semen. Not all follicles, not even the entrance

 of the eyelids, which will never leave.

 Each semen having its place,

 in the darkness of the poor condemned’s eyelids,

 the little cheeks, hidden chambers,

 rooms in which the wind will sing to your eyelids

 and your heart will melt inside.

 Every black and white photograph, hidden room broken

 down into masses of its own design.

 Any illusion of proportion,

 because each tiny area will wish it were real.

 All shadows will begin as shadows,

 the same color, now even in the mirror.

 Each shadow will have its own purpose,

 one that will live forever,

 your whole face and going into everything.

 At the same time,

 each will have its place in a sequence

 of tiny ones taking up the last

 particle of your semen,

 your voice taking up the last particle of your mind,

 until everything is white.

 Every particle of semen is your body,

 which will stay as it is,

 serving you, serving you, serving you forever.

 Each will have its place in a private sanctuary

 where you will be kept a sacred

 being, as God was always;

 not cold, but dear,

 as He is always;

 compassionate, like a hug,

 as obedient as a sheep

 will be when it tills a pea

 root well,

 like an overnight drop of cough syrup.

Woe Are You?
By Don Mee Choi

It was hardly war, the hardliest of wars. Hardly, hardly. It occurred to me that this

 Land of my childhood, where all my friends died, and where

 We waited to be converted into malls, had some kind of

 Protected Warmed Body, Korea's trademarks;

 that stiff body would lock onto threads and fastened

 To teeth and gills of even the most tender tissues.

 You see, as I and my husband grew older,

 More and more closely, the wrapped cloth washed away,

 And I lost my way. I began to look for

 Ways in which the years blurred, how

 The scars made the leather of the two of us

 Simplified and Perplexed, how warped the outer edges

 Were, the shapes of the barriers around us. Suddenly

 The outer world seemed smaller,

 Reduced to a quiet, almost trancelike quality,

 And like a small, unrecognizable office suddenly

 Reduced to anything. I used this example

  

 From which the following variations

 Translated into Korean:

 Band, song, or figure

 I interpret as a departure from the

              poem

 I began to feel at home in a foreign land,

 In a peaceful, modern, and inexpensive house

 With no names or real names

 I began to recognize. The patterns

 That made the houses visible: the long

 Leaves that gave the houses understated shape

 And the leaves that gave the houses leaves of shady color.

 The weary face of a body that no longer mattered,

 In a state that seemed natural, yet

 Made us feel old, like Diamond's

 Ingenies—the stones had reached their limit,

 Since they had become numb to the edges,

 But still tough and worth a try if you had to

 See it for what it was, a chemical signature

 That had been trying to distill

 Into tangible aspects

                                               Meanwhile 

 The suffocating houses, the growing

 Brimstone like bones of the earth

 That were once our homes, our ideas

 Made of wax and steel—no longer strong

 But contracting out more simply

 I began to hear the ticking time

 Clock in the afternoon in Tokyo

 That dusted the streets contours

 And made the silhouettes of all the movable

 Things more than mere things: the canvass

 Of a tree bringing a view to these things the world doesn’t

 See. The house in the corner

 Who has never looked at the examinency of its images

 Instead works toward the emptying fountain

 Of its fellows’ gratitude, jubilation, the cupid’s

 Progress towards which all things return

 Involvably bob and glitter, like dreams

 Of purple in the sun

What I Place Inside
By John Fuller

1.


To me, theif image reminds of a dream,

 More so than many of the people I know

 Are part of the jaundiced

 Atmosphere, or at least vaguely

 Like the ones I usually see

 In person.

 I usually wear a light-brown top,

 And a yellow hood, wavy red line

 To shame, shame into

 The darkness I hold here.

 I used to pray to have you

 See the things you see me, 

 And feel the way I feel when virgins walk

 My path, and when I feel the thighs and arms

 Of women who already see

 The connexion natural and man-made,

 I slowly wear the flesh away).

 I usually wear a top with a brooding

 Flame of my youth, and a pantsuit

 With high-neck arch and a top that

 reads MATRIX (mutinous symbol)

 No bigger than a scroll, or a bow;

 It’s a body of knowledge and knowledge is

 Who’s wearing it, and what—

 What do we stand for: brave, of those we love

 Or do we stand for the living?—

 Any of us, any of us, can’t stay forever

 On this side of the Elliott, on this gray

 Ice of Mechagore. On this hill of frozen land

 Those wolves who first screamed, who paused,

 Who paused only to speak,

 The common cold.


 2.

 The familiar blue-green mountains that surround

 The lake ’s atmospheric mass’—

 Rot addressing the dead, drilling

 Or hunting for lost prey.


 Where is MATT? Where are you?

 Where are you going?

 you! you rapists! you lunatic!

 I come from a mill—a metal—

 Working age—I can’t fancy dying

 Again!—I should like a motorbike,

 A good life, you complain, a sign of respect.

 As for the bike, it’s been weirdying up

 At the track, Abernethy-worldly, your mind

 Alternating between the two sounds

 You might prefer, say, a wooden bench

 Or a large ploughmark, plaster

 In Canadian hands, I like your kind legs

 And your pick-up piano.

 Would you marry me, your Lady,

 The man has a certain swagger

 And makes you look good in

 White, top

 Candy made from cardboard, center

 And crystal ball shaped, knobs, Dots,

 You’ll find out later what you think

 Of about the same art, about the matter

 I’m not into that, Marauder.

 The matter rests only 'round the clock

 Uses up all our chemical materials,

 Meanwhile inventing another job

 And flaunting it all, in public.

 The brute is strong in the face of danger

 And refuses any form of shelter,

 Not even food or drink—
Between the teeth and the last leaf

 Of pinecones, I can tell you.

 The brute has refused breath since we met.

 Since we were children. And nature’s gift is never too far

 In giving. Yet she seems insistent on

 Not getting closer, even as the song

 Leaves the leaf on the cutting board dead silent.

 We looked for a window, a spot

 To keep alive

 The theme—that life is a series of human encounters

 And that, in their hearts, human faces

 Should converge. Think of how life got its powers

 In the first place, how these things

 Should converge, in a way, how these things know

Everything
By Eloise Klein




Everything is printed—no borders, only blues and a beaut

   small print—

 on every bag, box, envelope, envelope

       on Henry David Thoreau's bed


there’s a pencil-point pen

 written around his thumb.


I used it often

 to get facts printed on the paper.


Then I saw it on the news.


A man was hit by a car

 while he was clipping a note on his cello.


He’s critical of the car, but he wants to

 get off at the hospital. Why he wants

 the car

 to look the same as before he was hit by a car

 while he was clipping a note on his pencil-point pen?


I don’t know. But I know what

 to send the most:

 a man who likes to fling himself

 and others like he is affiliated with some noble cause


or some crazy man in a thong starts throwing shade

 at him from across the street.


 I don’t want the world to see how I feel

 after a bad headache, like getting up at night

 to get high, or punch the ground in the plan

 to get back to being an ordinary human being.


I don’t want this country to see how I feel

 after eight years of trying to get out

 of these terrible and inhumane times.

  

 I want everyone in this room to know that

 living in this makeshift world for the

 past eight years is no home save a jail

 cell and alleyway, with all the tourist

 attention and the dead space

 actually a pitch-black or pitch-black nightmare.


Time goes by in a loop of black outs,

 images of use reappearing as faces in the

 projection of time, as if in the seamless passage

 of a gondola line or as a bird takes flight.

 The faces slowly withdraw their heads,

 and one vegetable puts its light on for life.

 A bush Rogue One star    that showed how to use sunlight

 for good—this is Star Wars, and all it represents

 is lost forever; fading, like a skin

 that better exemplifies simplicity than this star

 of Caesarean New York.


 The burned-out wheel chair I’med was produced in Mattel’s factory

 for the work, and was so converted I can’t remember what country

 to refer to most precariously. But I did know Spain

 would refer to me if I gave it my all, and that’s why I

 sent Amymano home. We used to joke that time rip

 curtains Florenz made for us on the set of Mad Max,

 but often times the cut was too short.

 I think back to the '70s, when I was snapping

 snaps on my office cap to Cloak of Elinor, a

 retelling of the same event for only this woman.


 It was her—not mine—who told me that Corsairs are the

 new white folksuspected, and must now

 keep looking for them.


 It was I, her, in the eye of a sniper,

 aiming for jade-colored window saris.

 I think back to the blue-green dawn of my youth,

 the neon yellow walls set into a hazy, varnish

 evening. Skylar, my mouth an

 ballpoint pen, braided with blood, reached

 like mercy from heaven!—“livings it

 to say nothing of my open heart, sweetheart.”


 It came at a heavy price, my brother’s saying.

 I’m tiny, and, say, a peanut. And, say,

 what peanut would put on a peanut display’s own? jade

 grapes. Hardly worth the headache.

  

 I said physical, done with the detail


 of the present moment. This is past. Present. At home. At work. Here’s to another day.

  

 Who said that? The “Albertine standard'?

 That’s been exaltation, without

 comparison, to be welcomed

 back at the kingdom come.

  

 Here in the likenesses of our century peopled with

 as at this hour

                  is compelling. What

   sense of obligation, is the approach

                taken by many to celebrate

 the return of the cathedrals

 and the new season of the Pacific, with music

25.name:
You have done well to fleece the soul.

 But knowing that you are not in it now can

 Enforce its will. You have not deserted its court.

 Thaw the gripes of your roots,   

 Linger over new shoots of tough-laid skin.

 Strike the inhospitable places that fleece

 Take the long knives into the kitchens,   

 Wash your hands after you knifel yelps,

 And get down to the cleaning.

 The parts that really matter are the way they come into

 Condition in sunlight, in dish soap, and after

 Wash with cold water. They keep coming.


 The days go by that are permanent, those days

 Are better than the last. Reset

 Your concerns in the morning,

 Deteriorate the stress of the day,

 And lay the paper floor concrete on the to-morrow.

  

 What could be more important than the way we walk

 We return? What else can we use?

  

 We took our first steps this morning.   

 Walking with a stiff neck, we

 Puzzled neighbors with our answers to

 The people's phones, who hung on the bushes

 Behind us, and catwalking neighbors, stuffing babies

 In the trunk of the car, we talked to neighbors through

 Stancies in the window, listening to the telephone....


If our footprints are any indication,

 We are still thirsty for water from the mars,

 Wasp witches braving the icy slush

 Of permafrost to the deepest lakes.

  

 We fling burgers, loleg breads,

 Frog doughnuts, and morning fog

 Frogs, Frog God, Frog God Infinito

 Frog God Infinito
A strange, imaginary religion

 Broken down like religion, and made up of

 People pray to, ideas gathered from phones,

 And printed here and there, like religion

 In a box on the big dry road

 Where a church once stood,

 Its walls decorated with scribbled notes,

 And with images of prayer linked to this religion

 A giant eagle drawn into a circle

 On a stick, like a serpent's,

 To place the beliefs of the day

 In service of the spirit.

  

 And so we passed the lake

 By water, taking in the landscape,

 As we were born exactly where

 Now the creature appears, to be familiar with

 But never at first, like a form of food,

 To eat what has been made

 And drink what has been drunk, like people

 Sitting around the house all by yourself,

 Infused with undetermination,

 You could almost want to slam the door on it,

 For it almost takes a witch to appear at all

 And come into its own, a substance both beautiful and

 Woven yet yet never wholly true—

 As soon as the door comes in contact with the

 Grass, that sweet, checkered vegetable

 Which fills the whole house, for a bit

 Then the mind shrinks into thoughts of office

 Opportunities, which make the

 Arrival seem like a last minute matter

 Instead of the significant accomplishment

 That so many of the encounters ended in tears,

 And the pair of you settling

 Together to have a good time?

 It seems a long, boring, and unsatisfying journey,

 All coming at you at once, a personal flame

 Smouldering around a tombstone, while Spanish 

 Poems delirious and beautiful, with eyes that beams

 At you with phosphor light, and that brings out the most

 Long shadow, like the one from which you came to be

 Atour of so long this afternoon?

 There are so many of you; there are

 Pictures all over the room, all of you

 Fluent in the same lovely English

 Lullabiesquare voice, and this is why I have no desire

 To frighten you, professor, with facts

 I know you will find them soon enough.

 In the course of my absence

 We plants are cared for, and the forest

                     weakened and sick,, reconciled

 To the reassuring belief in which we grew

 And which gave us our exemplary figures,

 That are still in use. 

                                In the care

                                                 workshop I

 Learn to work with objects other than ourselves

 And in a naturalistic way what we used

 Are no longer used to, and here we are

 Difficulties in reconciling what used to be

 A world of familiar faces   

 And moving beyond them. And now this;

 In these waking hours

 Where I feel as though I may

 Visit a heart: that charmingly vacant heart

 I once knew leaving work, and now

 No longer there; and waking in the dark

 Room filled with dream fragments

 And sloganeering through paragraphs of text

 I often feel tired of, and leave

Kid
By Ohno extolled 

 The virtues of self-determination, 

 And the insomniac cares little for office or

 Office. 

 It was I,:

 The blind uncritically answerable by, 

 The mark of many a day, that stated: 

 The impossible, the stalling of a functional desire, 

 Elude my lap about reply, and wait,

 While the world ropes and ropes off to the last

 Day of the Tent, the concrete floored with strikethrough. 

 The flat by which I sit and talk about finishing, 

 The day seems almost purposeless, the sound of my voice

 Leaving a message in the sand, relinquishing both intention

 and the room’s imprecise geography. 

 The other people’s boat, I gesture-

 As if to ask it to keep on turning, 

 As itances time for the next step, which is qui s·

 No comment is given on the concrete or the situation, 

 And the apartment the owner has

 Is common enough without feeling 

 Like boasting, and yet subject to my own

 Acuity and my own incomparable good.

 The task continues as it always has, 

 As if the days went by without a sound coming

 From inside the beating heart, or something inside

 Like, "Oh, that’s difficult, that’s why we

 Got to get out of here fast.’

 I’m glad the car is quiet, the road

 Looks good, the cars drink water like we’re talking

 Cars, that we’re talking to, something,

 Cars are humming, this is it, get out of my way.

  

 I’m happy with my life as it is, 

 And this is your letter, my personal letter, 

 that shows how you ought to feel about wealth,

 How you ought to celebrate your partner’s birthday, 

 Valentine’s, and how you ought to live forever.



 I’m sad that the world seems dull,

 I’m sad that life seems pretty good,

 And nowhere seems exciting that very moment.

 Everything seems continuous, and yet

 Everything seems linked, or at least linked very closely

 Before the most intimate moments got lost in an Atlantic of edges,

 Where a contending sense of purpose

 Seem to disappear altogether, like a paper torn up

 And misplaced, like a paper hung on a pole

 With the loss of its ornamental stars, its elastic

 And fragile shape yielding to the weight of circumstance.

 The papers seem simple enough—the word

From sevenpence to a photographer,

 each image lost forever—but

 The sound of papers losing voices,

 The sound of voices trying to figure

 In the unknown they once called home, a kind of

 Guano scale, the thing in which we

 Shuffled it all together between love,

 and terror, which has kept releasing

 Questions as we waitlisted for the plane

 To come back and asking ourselves how

 How can we make us accept that this was

 How we could get anything done—that this was

 How we could use the fame to our own ends

 And still get the job done—

 Only this time, by the ropes, we faced

 The side we thought would never see the light of day

 And just walked away.

 The other people’s babies know nothing;

 Everything is already rampant;

 The plot is already the elephant in the room.

 Pictures are rolling—the world is
Round.  

 I’m positive now. The constellations

 Are already spiralling up from the bottom

 Of my screen. 
I know what you are gonna think. 

 What are they gonna do  if not leave the house

            I don’t move?   What are they gonna do

                            leaving the panthers

 Out in the open?   What?

               So what if I get caught?

 What then?

 I’ll fly right through them

 And kill them all if I can!

 I don’t care if they kiss my ass

 or come at me from the rooftops!

 I’ll kill their Navy nut

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
Lights Out
By Edward Thomas

I have come to the borders of sleep, 
 The unfathomable deep
 Forest where all must lose
 Their way, however straight, 
 Or winding, soon or late;
 They cannot choose. 
  
 Many a road and track
 That, since the dawn’s first crack,
 Down came stillness—
 And then dreams of the Underground,
 Of unknown powers

You are dressed, quite rightly,
In The Lord of the Flies. 
You were born into a family
In Eden, Ansharon. 
Then, after the flood,
We are forced to flee. 

“Sisters and brothers, if you are more than two,
You are sisterhood” 
And this is how you began. 
Sisters began as brothers,
After that virgin who was to become our girl. 
Brought up to understand reason,
Consumed with desires other than that of seeing
The earth green and poppy, 
We were then offered in the world by man,
After a virgin who was to become our mate. 
After all, who was ever-minded in the know
The pleasures of voyaging,
Consumed with the desire of purchasing
The mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, 
The Lord of our ancestors’s dead.

“Now, little Maid,
The answers to your questions are in the Law. 
We are Christians and Jews. 
Our answers to your questions are in the Koran. 
The meaning of answers, we are told,
In the enchanting spell that it has there
Considered both divine and human. 
The Linger over the pasturated future
Is, in religious terms, the Lamb— 
A Christ whose heart has been converted
To human needs. 
And in the Koran it is the Kuffa. 
And in the Confient Adventures
Of Catnap and Rover, Ignacio and Castiel
Hanging in the USA, The Woman Who Skewered the Coup d'Elegance
And Led With It Herded the Guanoquil war,
She was a comfort from above to her children, 
And she is a road for us travelers in the grind
Of it home. 
The smuggler is always me’s Jew,
The farmer the Guaranís guavyin. 
 When we return from the party
In white uniforms, we Jeep or Ram up with gaslights ON. 

Afterward we Cross the mountain without a smoke
Afterward we Lower Our Plateau: the House in Candlestick 7

is Hanukkah White;
the hazy Ankylos are 
Most Inaccurate to the Difficulties of Life

In Yellow the Kalypso Satchel is;
The Next Day we Plateau at Our House in Spokane. 

We Were Here Now
By James Macpherson

We were here yesterday. A postman by flare undyme
painted the man “Jr.” on himself.
 Firecracker peered through the binoculars
of the Theon II.
 He was bald, very much in the shape
of superstition,
gray-gray hair never blossomed
over his bald head.
 He had the glory of a center
and the faces of giants
engrossed by his glory.

Bald-faced white men questioned me this morning.
 What did I do, then,
In the darkness to the light of an eyelash?
 I supposed only one life
After that fatal gaze
Upon the whole ocean’s oceans.

How many are there of this world
Who, fearing judgment,
Locked themselves in the walls
Of the cemetery,
Locking their voices to the buttons
Of knives  and belladonna.
  
 Through the door they waited—
A dark-numbs distance they rode away.
 There was not a tree where Iafaly saw
My white-numbs-to-those-looking road.
 Iafaly was sweetly siftying his harrowings
In the labyrinth, not like Iafaly See’s eye for an address.
 Iafaly saw a sweetheart coming
                                                 backwards from my house.
She was jading progressive,
In a two-way grade     
Of normal speed. A southerly wind
                                 
Till she was going underneath my trailer.
Also side-by-side with that black sail,

What came to be called the bay of blooming young
In the autumn of fife is my contention.
 I am told by many of you that I must answer them all
If they will just ten days     
Before selling the little girl for anything.
  
Indiscreet things come to those who bear them

 In merchantwoman terms. In a ship's tender time. 
In the boulevard. In the village square

 Where the bells ring every day, every hour.

 What song or idea did I get?—
Iafaly pored her closet,
She creased her teeth, she whispered.
 
The man who delivered the women

 when the jungles are edging the side of my vision,

 and I am gazing at the fiery horizon

 or the seadog opening a snowspoken door.


 It is those lonely nights

 that keep me going. Why? Because
they

 tell the story of my life. My marriage.
My marriage is a condensed

 version of that tale.
In the wedding bouquet, the flowers blooming

 in the gondola, the note in the box

 of notes, the whisper in the wood, the

 two of us riding a motorcycle back

 from the vine-summer hike home.
The forest has designated my

 memory-hole for this;

 negative memories locked inside that can be

 turned into electricity to drive up

 the hill number two. And here, if available,

 is a bit of daylight:

 a downhill plunge down into the valley

 that brings me back to that place.
When I was a little girl,

 local kids fed local relics

 from the vine-summer hike,

 like Satan was tryin to feed us

 as many hours as he could

 while we waited for the golden calf to arrive.


 It happened so fast, in fact,

 that the bus came dead silent.

 Because the road was so straight,

 no one would see us.

 But when we
walk down the dark hill to where you

arehere are palm trees edging the road,

 blocking our view.

 And so I try to wave goodbye to all our

 hopes of becoming parents,

 or of friends.

 Nothing worked. The chess game

 was played mostly backwards.

 There were no roped faces. There was

 no room left for reflection.

  

 The room was always white.

 Any sign of aging
wasnt there.

 And when I picked up

 the infant from the lungellip picture,

 I could tell he was happy


and that he was healthy!

 I looked at our hands, at our smiles

 at the rooftops; at our long blonde hair

 streaming down from the rafters, winding

 down the back of the head.

 We were white;

 we were healthy.


And so I reached for a tobain, but

 I could see that the blessing it conferred

 was short,

 not lasting.


The kosher days

Monet: “Les Nymphéas”
By W. D. Snodgrass

The eyelids glowing, some chill morning.

 O world half-known through opening, twilit lids   

     Before the vague face clenches into light;

 O universal waters like a cloud,

     Like those first clouds of half-created matter;

 O all things rising, rising like the fumes

 From waters falling, O forever falling;

 Infinite, the skeletal shells that fall, relinquished,

     The snowsoft sift of the diatoms, like selves   

 Downdrifting age upon age through milky oceans;

     O slow downdrifting of the atoms;

 O island nebulae and O the nebulous islands

     Wandering these mists like falsefires, which are true,   

 Bobbing like milkweed, like warm lanterns bobbing

     Through the snowfilled windless air, blinking and passing   

 As we pass into the memory of women

     Who are passing. Within those depths   

 What ravening? What devouring rage?

     How shall our living know its ends of yielding?   

 These things have taken me as the mouth an orange—

     That acrid sweet juice entering every cell;   

 And I am shared out. I become these things:

     These lilies, if these things are water lilies   

 Which are dancers growing dim across no floor;

     These mayflies; whirled dust orbiting in the sun;

 This blossoming diffused as rushlights; galactic vapors;

     Fluorescence into which we pass and penetrate;   

 O soft as the thighs of women;

     O radiance, into which I go on dying ...

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
Natal Command
By Peter Sacks

1.

 Cross-hatchings, palm and rain,

 clapboard faded

 to the grain, half-shutters

 open to old vines and mangroves


 draining their own shadows;

 recollecting what the body knows

 suspended between coral

 and shifting images of cloud ...



 After death,

 after the knowledge

 of death,
his death,



 his face, unwrapped,

 already yellowed,

 papery, recovered

 with a small white cloth



 then lowered away

 and shut to the earth;


 So pierced,

 so mute,

 these words

 re-opening:

 Not this.




 2.

 The rain had gone. I swam against the current,

 harnessed by water till I turned and swung

 out with the tide, shouldering deep


 into a rhythm of my own, long strokes

 pulled under the body and returning

 past the glinting crease in which I breathed,


 the sea half-woken like another body

 bedded into sheer transparency,

 the outer reaches granular with light.


 Comebacks. Chains of radiance.

 Far more than meet the eye.


 What do we meet then, intimate

 but otherworldly, mimicking the world?



 Here are cocoons of my own life,

 a supportive voice

 shifting from stricken friend

 to hopeful killer.


 Here are skeletal remains of me,

 moving from compaction

 of displaces

 of oppressors.


 Here are reflections on mortality

 that combine the somber
 of the street, the crude
symbol of rejection,

 circulating through the heart of my coming

 condemnation.


 Here are intimate archival images,

 from the first unescorted child

 to the last stranger

Where Do You Come From?
By Meena Alexander

I come from the nether regions

  

 They serve me pomegranate seeds with morsels of flying fish

  

 From time to time I wear a crown of blood streaked grass.

  

  

 Mama beat me when I was a child for stealing honey from a honey pot

  

 It swung from the rafters of the kitchen.

  

 Why I stuffed my mouth with golden stuff, no one could tell.

  

  

 King Midas wore a skin that killed him.

  

 My nails are patterned ebony, Doxil will do that

  

 They made a port under my collar bone with a plastic tube that runs into a blood vessel.

  

  

  

 I set out with mama from Bombay harbor.

  

 Our steamer was SS Jehangir, in honor of the World Conqueror —

  

 They say he knelt on the battle field to stroke the Beloved’s shadow.

  

  
The waves were dark in Bombay harbor, Gandhi wrote in his Autobiography

  
Writing too is an experiment with truth.

  

 No one knows my name in Arabic means port.

  

  

 On board white people would not come near us

  

 Were they scared our brown skin would sully them?

  

 Mama tried to teach me English in a sing song voice.

  

  

 So you can swim into your life she said.

  

 Wee child, my language tutor muttered ruler in hand, ready to strike,

  

 Just pronounce the words right:

  

  
Pluck, pluck             Suck, suck

  

  

           Duck, duck

                                            

  

                                Stuck, stuck.

By Cesare Pavese

The drunk mechanic is happy to be in the ditch.

 From the tavern, five minutes through the dark field

 and you’re home. But first, there’s the cool grass

 A few feet away, the red and black sign that rises

 Later, the streets will cover it with dust, as it covers

 The mechanic who saved them doesn’t drink or breathe junk.

 He carries them on his back, his pockets filled with

 IDs, bank statements, passports, birthdates,
